text:
*[Bug 18173] Man page for lm.fit is very brief about the circumstances when to use*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18173>

Holly Cui (<mailto:yifan.cui@duke.edu|yifan.cui@duke.edu>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |yifan.cui@duke.edu

--- Comment #1 from Holly Cui (<mailto:yifan.cui@duke.edu|yifan.cui@duke.edu>) ---
(In reply to k_bugzilla from comment #0)
Based on the issue of the lm.fit documentation, we propose several edits below:

1. In the lm.fit help [Description] section, the sentences below:

"These should usually not be used directly unless by experienced users.
.lm.fit() is a bare-bones wrapper to the innermost QR-based C code, on which
glm.fit and lsfit are also based, for even more experienced users."

could be replaced by:

lm() creates an input design matrix using the data and formula specified in the
user's model, and is intended to be used directly; a user with a pre-calculated
design matrix may call lm.fit or .lm.fit, but otherwise should use lm().

-----

2. In the lm.fit help [References] section, the sentences below:

"lm which you should use for linear least squares regression, unless you know
better."

could be replaced by:

lm, which calls lm.fit as a helper function.
.lm.fit is a wrapper to the C code that performs QR decomposition.

elements.text: [Bug 18173] Man page for lm.fit is very brief about the circumstances when to use

) ---
(In reply to k_bugzilla from comment #0)
Based on the issue of the lm.fit documentation, we propose several edits below:

1. In the lm.fit help [Description] section, the sentences below:

"These should usually not be used directly unless by experienced users.
.lm.fit() is a bare-bones wrapper to the innermost QR-based C code, on which
glm.fit and lsfit are also based, for even more experienced users."

could be replaced by:

lm() creates an input design matrix using the data and formula specified in the
user's model, and is intended to be used directly; a user with a pre-calculated
design matrix may call lm.fit or .lm.fit, but otherwise should use lm().

-----

2. In the lm.fit help [References] section, the sentences below:

"lm which you should use for linear least squares regression, unless you know
better."

could be replaced by:

lm, which calls lm.fit as a helper function.
.lm.fit is a wrapper to the C code that performs QR decomposition.

text:
*[Bug 18186] Any broken symlinks prevent R CMD build from running, even if .Rbuildignored.*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18186>

Zhian Kamvar (<mailto:zkamvar@gmail.com|zkamvar@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |zkamvar@gmail.com

--- Comment #2 from Zhian Kamvar (<mailto:zkamvar@gmail.com|zkamvar@gmail.com>) ---
Created attachment 3389
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3389&action=edit>
exclude files before copying to temporary build direcotry

This patch was authored by Jane He (who is currently applying for a Bugzilla
account) and myself at the R dev day in Seattle, WA USA.

This patch applies the second strategy proposed in comment #1 by explicitly
excluding the ignored files _before_ they are sent to the temporary build
directory.

In practice, we moved the code that collates the exclude list above the copy
commands, ensured the working directories were correct, and removed the unlink
commands. We ran `make check-dev` on both Mac and Ubuntu Linux and found no
errors.
